p.s: I think saying that Shakespeare never grows old and that He continues to inspire each new generation is not the right way to express it, because of several reasons.
When you're discussing about the importance of Shakespeare being taught at school you have to see it from two different perspectives.
On the one hand you have the historical knowledge you get if you talk about ShakespearShakespeare.
Also you learn mental tippstips to develop yourself.
On the other hand, Shakespeare uses a very old form of the englishEnglish language which makes it very difficult, in my opinion, to read and the most important thing, to understand the text.
If you're able to understand Shakespear'sShakespeare's texts I think that it can be very interesting and you can get thoughttaught by the content itself.
But you always have to consider that Shakespeare lived a very long time ago so you should prove the things the storysstories teach you are up-to-date.
So for non-native speaker I am divided if you should get thoughttaught Shakespeare at school.

Otherwise I think that for native englishEnglish speaker Shakespeare should be part of the school, because most of the aspects that are against teaching Shakespeare at school are not counting for native speakers.
You could compare it for example to Goethe in Germany.
He used an old language but for native germanGerman speakers it is easier to understand than for non-native speakers.
AlltogetherAltogether I think that it is right to teach Shakespeare at school but it should be in a way that non-native speakers could understand it more easily.

Also I think that many students are loosinglosing interest in Shakespeare, because it is that difficult and a long time ago, so I wouldn't say that he continues this inspiration if there comes no change.
